Award.AwardTitle: DDRIE: Economic Value of Crime Control: Evidence from a Large Investment in Police Infrastructure.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Economic models of criminal behavior have focused mainly on the effects of investment in policing on crime while ignoring the broader societal benefits of such investments. This research project uses the housing market to study the local welfare effects of a large investment in police infrastructure. Applying a research design based on the openings of police stations in the three large cities, the project studies the effects of public safety investments on crime and housing markets. Specifically, it measures the relationship among police investments, reductions in violent and non-violent crimes and changes in the prices of nearby residential properties. Initial results show that observable police presence reduce overall crime. However, the effect is local; it is within less than half of a mile, with no appreciable impact outside the area where the police stations are built. The researchers then use police station construction to calculate their effects on local housing prices and new construction. The researchers find statistically significant evidence that police stationsâ€™ openings increase housing values. The results of this research project provides insights on the effects of police on broader welfare of citizens as well as provide inputs into how to make local government investments efficiently. <br/><br/><br/>This DDRIE research project leverages new police station construction in neighborhoods in a number of cities over time to estimate the causal effects of police infrastructure on welfare of local communities. The project consists of two parts---the effects of police station construction on crime rates, and the effects of policing on housing markets. Using quasi-experimental variation in police station construction in neighborhoods and cities, this research project studies the short- and long- term cross-sectional and intertemporal changes in reported crime and finds that police station construction leads to reduction in local crime rates. This part of the project also explores the mechanisms through which police station construction affects reduction in crime, testing both deterrence and incapacitation channels. The second part of the project uses a hedonic pricing model to estimate the effects of crime reduction on property values, thus recovering the price elasticity of crime. This is a first attempt to estimate willingness to pay to avoid crime. The project develops a welfare analysis of crime control that accounts for individual heterogeneity and sorting. This research provides insights on the effects of policing on broader welfare of citizens as well as provide inputs into efficient local government investments decision making.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The social and economic impacts of policing go beyond reducing crime. On the one hand, the broader impacts of crime reductions include improvements in individuals' health and educational outcomes and the psychological effect of people feeling safer and having an active social life (Currie et al., 2020; Janke et al., 2016). On the other hand, policing can lead to excessive use of force and mistrust in the state (Ang, 2020; Bobo and Thompson, 2006).

When academics and policymakers evaluate crime interventions, they typically focus on the effects on crime rates alone, while the broader costs and benefits tend to be ignored. This is striking because the assessment of the social cost of crime is essential for the optimal allocation of resources towards policing. Wrong estimates might lead to either over-investing in policing or investing too little. In the United States, cities commonly spend a third or more of their municipal funds on policing, yet the estimated monetary benefits of these expenditures are unknown. 

This paper represents a step forward in understanding not only the efficacy of policing, but also, the broader costs of crime exposure in terms of the individuals' willingness to pay (WTP) to avoid crime. I study the effects of 100 newly constructed police stations in the three largest cities in Colombia by applying the hedonic pricing model in the context of policing and crime. A large multi-city evaluation allows for an accurate estimation of the average marginal WTP through changes in property values. Previous studies often faced three main challenges: (1) omitted variable bias, (2) lack of granular data to estimate the local effects of policing on crime and its costs, and (3) selection due to individual heterogeneity and residential sorting. My study accounts for all three challenges.

My results suggest two take-aways for policy design. First, the WTP to avoid crime can be used to make optimal policy decisions, such as how much to spend on programs that reduce crime. My results show that increasing the presence of police has a statistically and economically significant impact on crime and property values in the immediate vicinity, meaning that individuals would be willing to pay a high cost for policies that increase police presence and reduce crime. My estimates of the elasticity of property values with respect to crime are also considerably higher than those that conventional hedonic regressions would imply, such as cross-sectional or panel fixed effects specifications, suggesting that policing may have greater benefits than previous analyses have shown.

Second, my results show that the marginal benefits of increasing policing in low or high crime areas are similar. This implies that there are important returns to increasing police equally across neighborhoods, in contrast to the common wisdom of directing resources only to high crime areas. In general, crime policies should consider the heterogeneity in responses across locations. This is important because most police services operate under fixed budgets or a limited amount of police officers which allow only a fraction of the locations to be served with a higher intensity.
